NAME: Deeply Liveable Neighbourhoods I
DESCRIPTION:
Between 2021-23, @countermap.land launched fifteen engagement workshops led by artists, collectives, and community groups. Each of these gatherings worked to map experiences and histories of the land commonly excluded from mainstream cultural heritage discourse. Many of the workshops also questioned the agencies and legacies embedded in cartography. The image above is from a live-writing public workshop by @proforma.corps. 

This entry represents a workshop by proforma corps, who strive to use media-architecture installations to engage in site-specific conversations, reframe dialogue on neighborhood issues, and amplify solidarity, visibility, and legitimacy with the most vulnerable affected community members. These actions aim to bring about meaningful discourse on policy, design, and collective visioning capacity, as well as catalyzing attitudinal transformations surrounding social and community needs in the built environment. proforma corps, led by Bria Cole, is an open-format artist collective that creates and collaborates to organize guerrilla urban projection interventions in Tkaronto. Using visualization, media systems, and projection media, the collective aims to collectivize issues that benefit from public dialogue, fostering community engagement and awareness. Past collective members include Mark Francis, Blythe Haynes, and Sarah Keokkeok. 

"Deeply Liveable Neighborhoods" refers to the details that create culturally rich neighborhoods, which contrasts with the monetization of city buildings. proformacorps presents a live writing station and projection event, welcoming all to share their memories, desires and dreams of a Tkaronto that is liveable beyond the market.
 
 The live writing station included a custom light box containing a pen, sketchpad. A webcam recorded the live illustrations and writing and sent the image through an open source Max patch to convert the video into a vector-based video and projected onto a surface in public space. This participatory event elicited responses to an accompanying animated prompt "what makes a neighborhood deeply liveable?"

NAME: Cherries
DESCRIPTION:
Of all the things suspended
 in the air
 I didn't expect time to also
 be there with you
 Dangling, whirling, rustling
 In and on my mind
 Where all the currents of
 time move through you in 
 my mind
 I’m embedded in your
 conductive medium
 Where are you taking me? 
 I like the way you look at me
 from up there
 I wonder how many airs
 have moved through you
 Breath and not
 You give me the blueprint 
 for the sky
 But the sky turns
 sometimes
 Time stops sometimes
 Dangling, whirling, rustling
 
 Later I came to find that we
 were both only loosely fitted
 to the sphere of potential

__

NAME: “DANGER Deep Water Quicksand” in Wychwood Park
DESCRIPTION:
Algal surface tension
 broken by 
 unseen underneath.
 What secrets lie here?
 Who sunk here?
 Undisturbed silken depth,
 wooded frame,
 the city’s urban density 
 shows no signs here,
 no high rises here,
 in this green enclave within 
 gr$$n enclave.
 Former Victorian artist colony,
 former Taddle Creek,
 dammed up, bound, or
 buried,
 once a springtime gathering 
 place,
 solitude and tranquility 
 hoarded now,
 kept hidden by wealth.
 Road hum trickles through a 
 shuttered south gate,
 excess pool trickles down 
 grate,
 time is still here,
 time a dangerous illusion 
 here.

__

NAME: Nothing New Stays the Same
DESCRIPTION:
Then why should this new thing
 feel so dire? A fence
 a wall concave 
 on the corner.
 
 Bound now —
 
 it was open — 
 a convex
 so magic 
 fairies gathered 
 and foraged for belonging
 hidden under their leaves
  
 watched and shouted hums
 their wanders, hot summer eves 
 and in their gather 
 danced the fairies
 
 danced and sang
 densed and rang
 dawned and reigned
 and rejoiced in their findings
 until they got evicted.
 
 If this fence
 I wish
 were any different, 
 would the present
 here be 
 any less misplaced?
__

NAME: Views From an Ancient Shore
DESCRIPTION:
Here, 
 memories don’t whisper 
 tucked up above
 buzzing vistas, the swarming 
 sssshhhhhhhhh 
 of tall grasses
 dance in the wind.
 Standing on bygone bluffs 
 staring towers in the eye, 
 toward the saltless sea.
 
 A friend comes to me
 on the concrete canopy
 and his memory touches my leg. 
 I ask him, "What is it like 
 on the other side?"
 He says, "It's
 so high, but no horizon 
 in sight, just rushing storms
 signaled by the wind."

NAME: Baby Goose Door
DESCRIPTION:
There isn't far to fall
 Pour me in, refill myself
 Petals percolate the edges 
 of home and risk,
 Gravity feels foreign to my
 heart,
 And yet so much hangs over 
 me,
 I wish it was a womb
 Break me through, refill 
 again,
 sap inside a superficial 
 skeleton
 The potential seeps through
  its container everyday,
 When I defy myself I 
 abandon a truth,
 Now only to be found in 
 music,
 Seeking through the radio,
 Or the birds,
 Mother's pulse
 "Take me home! It's me!
 Let me into your baby goose 
 door!"
 
 
 What will become of what's 
 left?
 The litter must decompose, 
 but at what scale?
 I pray for a pathway clear 
 enough to see and weak 
 enough to move.
 I pray for you. Holding that
 door open, hand offered 
 outward.
 And a clear sky to rise my 
 gaze to.

__

NAME: How Do You Do It?
DESCRIPTION:
Arising complexity. I cross 
 the street.
 It’s comparison, 
 competition, the season of
 expression. Flowers.
 Your flowers. You flower. 
 You are a flower.
 Whose Choice, whose will. 
 Beauty is still here and I eat
 it. Admire it. Wonder at it. 
 Cross the street for it. Tickle
 my lips with it. Is it your
 intimacy, that I haven’t
 asked for? Asked your
 guardian. If I can linger,
 dwell. Love from far. Close 
 in…
 
 And who else is here. Flying
 ant like, your bee legs filling
 with orange pink pollen.
 
 I can’t leave. Now that I’ve
 stopped. I think you’re who 
 they call chestnut
 Aesculus parviflora…. 
 Passing ovaries…. 
 Fecunded…. ?

__

DESCRIPTION:
This Gumisistiy Youth program was led by artist Bruno Canadien. Canadien led the Tsuut'ina youth on a walk of the land at the Leighton Art Centre located in Treaty 7 territory (near Millarville), encouraging the youth to draw and investigate the land, vegitation, and animal presence aroung them. Stride Gallery is an artist-run centre located on the traditional territories of Tsuut’ina, Niitsitapi,
and Iyarhe Nakoda in Treaty 7, in a city colonially known as Calgary. Tsuut’ina Nation Youth Program (TNYP) operates from Tsuut’tina Nation, facilitating the Nation’s junior powwow and various youth programs. Since 2018, our organizations have been collaborating on a youth art program named Gumisistiy, which means “to persevere” or “to keep going” in Tsuut’ina.

Gumisistiy Youth Program tackles the question of access to art and reciprocal relationship
building between First Nations and art institutions. Our two organizations are building a lasting
relationship that fosters artistic growth and agency for the youth. Acknowledging the historically
racist and unsafe arts institutions, Gumisistiy connects Tsuut’ina youth and different art spaces
in the city through various art workshops. Artists lead programs to introduce their own practices
that are constantly expanding and reshaping what it means to be an Indigenous artist in this
moment. These artists offer potential role models and pathways to finding a creative voice and
self-expression for the youth. The program introduces ceremony to the colonial spaces, with the
intention of making Tsuut’ina ways of being porously present in Treaty 7 areas.

NAME: Esker Foundation, Fort Calgary
DESCRIPTION:
This Gumisistiy Youth program took place on the same day with in two seperate locations. The first was Esker Foundation led by Sachin Sudra. Sachin led grounding excersies before teaching the Tsuut'ina youth on how to prepare a group meal with healthy, ethically sourced ingredients (including bison, a traditional and cultural food source within their culture). The second part of the workshop led the youth after the meal to Fort Calgary, where they were guided by Kendall Jacobs, a traditional Knowledge Keeper also from Tsuut'ina Nation. Kendall provided the youth with the Tsuut'ina perspective and account of historical events and stories of Fort Calgary, including the making of Treaty 7.

NAME: Deane House
DESCRIPTION:
Deane House is a historic building and a garden that is currently a fine dining restaurant. Named for Captain Richard Burton Deane, the last superintendent of Calgary, Deane House is the only remaining North West Mounted Police (NWMP) building in Calgary. While the only documented history of Deane House, located right next to Fort Calgary, is only retold through a settler-colonial lens, Kendall Jacobs shared histories of Indigenous presence in this site. For example, there is a ghost of Deerfoot, who haunted the house for many years.

DESCRIPTION:
__

Between 2021-23, @countermap.land launched fifteen engagement workshops led by artists, collectives, and community groups. Each of these gatherings worked to map experiences and histories of the land commonly excluded from mainstream cultural heritage discourse. Many of the workshops also questioned the agencies and legacies embedded in cartography. This submission is from a workshop led by Gentle Geographies, Hives for Humanity and Keenan Marchand.

A statement from the organizers;  

"On the 100 block of East Hastings in what is colonially known as Vancouver, British Columbia, and which has many other names, including K’emk’em’elay, the Place Where the Maples Grow, the unceded lands and shared territories of the Musqueam, Squamish and Tsleil Wau’tuth Nations since time immemorial, time out of mind - there is a garden.  

It is from here that we explore themes of community care, sensory respite, ground truthing, growing governance and ask: beyond survival, beyond isolation - What is 'enough'? What helps in the struggle? What can we accomplish in a season?  In a year? In a lifetime?  And, how might we envision a world beyond capitalist exploitation?  Beyond policing?

Currently owned by Concord Pacific, the previous structure on this land was torn down in the 1990s and the land has been 'vacant' ever since.  While waiting to maximize value of the land, developers are incentivized to convert lots into class 8 community garden or public park use for the substantial tax break, where the developer pays about one third of the taxes they’d otherwise owe.

These gardens are deemed short-term aesthetic contributions to communities and promote hoarding land rather than considering access to land as essential for survival, especially where there is a lack of accessible land with the explicit intention for cultural uses of medicine growing, reconnecting with language, sweat lodge and dualling as unprogrammed space for sensory respite alongside a gathering venue for ceremony, celebration and memorial where we celebrate the seasons and lay seeds and plants into the land along with the memories of our loved ones.  Where we learn how to restore the connections severed by capitalist and colonial exploitation and extraction.

Despite decades of care, we have no lease, no first right of refusal, no alternatives and a sluggish entry point into discussions on East Hastings 100 block redevelopment strategies.  We feel the precarity deeply alongside increased policing while the drug poisoning crisis continues and the ongoing shortage of dignified housing and options for self-determined healing remain stagnant."
